--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
>
> At 22:=
34 10/11/2005, you wrote:
> >Colin Green wrote:
> >
> > >
> > >2) Changing =
the fitness function. We choose a function based on 
the
> > >problem at ha=
nd, so it doesn't seem sensible to switch to a 
different
> > >function. Bu=
t often we come up with different ways of 
evaluating netwoks
> > >for a gi=
ven problem and we often have discussions about what is 
the best
> > >func=
tion. What if we were to code up a few of theses different 
functions
> > >=
and allow NEAT to periodically switch between them. This then 
could be
> >=
 >something akin to an extinction event occuring in nature and 
changing
> =
> >the fitness landscape.
> > >
> > >
> > >
> >.... or if your function has=
 a bunch of measures that are 
weighted to
> >give a final fitness score yo=
u could just change the weighting
> >occasionally.
> 
> I have been toying =
with this.  e.g. because TTT-PPS involves 
testing 
> each individual over =
620-odd boards, you could regard the fitness 
of 
> each individual as a ve=
ctor or values (one value for each 
> board).  This still reduces to a sing=
le overall fitness if you sum 
> over the vector, but by keeping the values=
 separate for some 
> purposes, you might be keeping information that would=
 otherwise be 
discarded.
> 
> ((This is not specific to TTT, it would appl=
y just as well to any 
> case where the score is built as a sum over a set =
of test 
> cases.  Even co-evolution might be expressible this way, e.g. if=
 
each 
> individual plays against every other member of the population, 
t=
hen 
> that set of results is a fitness vector as well.))
> 
> You can use =
this to identify individuals with important new 
features, 
> even if their=
 overall score is low.  e.g. given two individuals, 
we 
> have the simple =
comparison of scores:
> 
> DScore(1, 2) =3D Score_1 - Score_2.
> 
> But we =
also can divide up the test-cases according to who passed 
them:
> 
> Commo=
nScore(1, 2) =3D Sum(Cases_Both_Pass);
> CommonFail(1, 2) =3D Sum(Cases_Bot=
h_Fail);
> Advantage(1, 2) =3D Sum(Cases_1_Passes_But_2_Fails);
> Advantage=
(2, 1) =3D Sum(Cases_2_Passes_But_1_Fails);
> 
> Thus, when 2 has a lower o=
verall score than 1, but a non-zero 
> Advantage(2, 1).  That tells us that=
 although 2 is a step back in 
> absolute fitness, it has discovered someth=
ing that 1 cannot do 
> (especially if 1 is the population leader, because =
the leader is 
> least likely to be missing anything obvious and least-like=
ly to be 
> able to acquire a new feature without losing some existing scor=
e).
> 
> Which might be a strong case for either:
> a) 2 being regarded as =
fitter than naive fitness woudl suppose, or,
> b) splitting 2 off into a ne=
w species to see if it can improve on 
its 
> new feature (with the scope t=
o merge it back later)
> c) trying hard to merge 1 and 2 right now
> 
>    =
      Ian
> 
> p.s. I don't really know anything about it, but doesn't one =
of the 
> classifier approaches work a little like this?  Maybe pareto?
> 
=

Yes actually you are beginning to invent your own version of pareto 
coevo=
lution there.  What you're describing is basically a pareto 
front.  There =
is a lot of work on coevolving game players using a 
pareto front by Sevan =
Ficici, Edwin De Jong, and Anthony Bucci.  For 
example, this paper by Edwi=
n De Jong is about a "Pareto Archive" for 
coevolution:

www.cs.uu.nl/~dejo=
ng/publications/gecco04coev.pdf 

Unfortunately, while such methods integra=
te some great ideas, they 
still have some big drawbacks, mostly in terms o=
f computation time.  
It gets very expensive maintaining that pareto front.=
  Also there is 
some debate about which part of the pareto front is import=
ant, but 
that is very recent (actually I saw Anthony Bucci discussing this=
 
question just this month at the AAAI Fall Symposium on coevolution).

ken=
